abstract.p: The Berlin Heart Excor (BHE) assist device has become our standard mechanical support device for long-term support in children with heart failure. We report two useful surgical modifications for the implantation of the BHE in the pediatric population, improving ease of implantation as well as subsequent surgical procedures at the time of explantation or transplantation. The first modification entails the use of a polytetrafluoroethylene graft for cannulation via the innominate artery for arterial perfusion during cardiopulmonary bypass. This graft is preserved and reused for institution of bypass at the time of transplantation or explantation of the device after recovery. The second modification consists of an extension of the BHE arterial cannula using a length of knitted polyester graft. This allows for improved positioning of the arterial cannula in the ascending aorta or main pulmonary artery, facilitates vascular anastomosis, and improves hemostasis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Berlin Heart Excor (BHE) assist device (Berlin Heart AG, Berlin, Germany) has become the most widely used ventricular assist device (VAD) for the treatment of heart failure in the pediatric population. 1,2 Since its introduction to the European market in 2005, it has been implanted in nearly 900 patients around the world. The device has been used successfully to support pediatric patients with dilated cardiomyopathy as well as in an increasing number of patients with congenital heart disease. The available cannula and ventricle configurations allow for the support of wide range of patients with diverse anatomical and pathological considerations. Case reports and series have documented successful support up to 591 days attesting to the reliability and versatility of the device.

We performed our first implantation of the BHE in a child in 2005. With growing experience, our implantation technique has evolved to address some of the difficulties experienced in particular in the pediatric population. We would like to present two surgical modifications introduced in our unit, which we have found particularly useful to facilitate not only implantation in small children but also subsequent explantation and/or transplantation. We review the impact that these developments have had on surgical outcomes in our pediatric heart failure population.

sec.title: Description of Surgical Techniques
sec.p: Our institutional review board approved the development of a mechanical circulatory support program as well as any required modifications in implantation technique. The first modification involves the use of a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) tube graft (Goretex, Gore & Associates, Flagstaff, Arizona) to provide arterial inflow via the innominate artery for perfusion during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). The graft is anastomosed to the innominate artery using a continuous 7/0 or 8/0 monofilament polypropylene suture after application of a side-biting clamp. The hemostasis of the anastomosis is secured, the graft is flushed with heparinized saline, and the patient is heparinized for CPB. An adequate length of graft (typically 4-5 cm) is used to allow the arterial cannula to be inserted into it outside of the chest. At this stage, the appropriate arterial cannula tip is inserted in the distal end of shunt and fixed with two silk ties (Figure 1). The cannula is then connected to the CPB circuit after careful de-airing. After completion of the VAD implantation procedure, the arterial cannula is removed from the graft, which is then closed with a titanium vascular clip at the insertion point, with two further clips placed on its length. The graft is then placed in the suprasternal space just above the innominate vein and the chest closed per normal routine. At reoperation, the graft is usually easily dissected out from the suprasternal space and allows for easy access for arterial cannulation (Figure 2). A side-biting clamp is again applied widely across the innominate artery and the occluding titanium clips removed. The graft is thoroughly irrigated with heparinized saline via a rigid cannula to expel any clot. A brief release of the side-biting clamp confirms patency and the absence of thrombus. Before the arterial cannula is fixed to the graft, any remaining air is carefully expelled.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Since the introduction of the BHE device to our practice in 2005, we have implanted 84 devices in 53 pediatric patients, totaling 2742 days of circulatory support. Support was biventricular VAD (BiVAD) in 32, left VAD (LVAD) in 27 two-ventricle patients, and Univentricular Assist Device in 4 single ventricle patients. We have used a PTFE graft to cannulate the innominate artery in 15 patients with a median age of 8 months (range 0.1-105.0) and mean weight of 9 kg (range 3-20). The graft diameter was 3 mm in one, 3.5 mm in six, and 4 mm in eight patients. We have not observed any difference in the rate of cerebral thromboembolic events during VAD support (25% vs 20%; P = 0.5). Similarly, we have carefully monitored clinically for neurological complications at the time of graft reuse. The graft has been successfully reused for arterial cannulation in 14 patients (once in ten patients, twice in three patients, and three times in one patient). Reuse of the graft occurred after a median of 25 days (range 4-78 days) from implantation. We have not observed any neurological event directly attributable to this technique. Five patients in whom a graft was used for cannulation had neurological events. One had a presupport right internal capsule infarct and two had left middle cerebral artery embolic events while on VAD support. One patient had hemorrhage into an existing presupport infarct in the left cerebral circulation. One more patient had recurrent bilateral cerebral thromboembolic events while on VAD support (three documented episodes) and a further right thalamic infarct peritransplant. Surgical bleeding complications have reduced over time, with no patients using the modified BHE outflow cannula requiring reexploration for bleeding versus 50% in the remainder of our cohort (P = .003, Fisher exact test). Mediastinal drain losses at 24 hours (13 ± 14 vs 28 ± 17 mL/kg, P = .002, median ± interquartile range [IQR], Mann-Whitney U test) were significantly lower and there was a trend toward a lower requirement for postoperative packed red cell transfusion (0 ± 10 vs 9 ± 21 mL/kg; P = .1, median ± IQR, Mann-Whitney U test). We have not observed any negative impact of altering the BHE outflow cannula in the described manner on VAD driving pressures nor the rate of cerebral thromboembolic events (10% vs 24% in modified vs standard cannulation, respectively; Fisher exact test, P = .26).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The availability of smaller volume pumps and cannulae has made longer term mechanical support possible in children but several challenges remain. The smaller relative size of the chest and great vessels can make cannula placement particularly challenging. Several modified techniques of device implantation have been reported in literature. 3,4 We have found the technique described by Nguyen 3 particularly useful as the extension of the BHE outflow cannula in this manner allows it to lie in a more natural position in small children with ventricular hypertrophy/dilatation. The modification allows the aortic anastomosis to be undertaken without resorting to aortic cross-clamping, therefore avoiding ischemic injury to the right ventricle and possibly reducing the requirement of RVAD. In addition, we have found the anastomosis easier to perform to the polyester graft than the sewing cuff of the original cannula. We believe that the polyester extension provides some flexibility to the connection between the arterial cannula and the great arteries. We have found hemostasis to be more easily achieved with this extended cannula possibly because of the improved flexibility, but increased experience and a reduction in the proportion of patients receiving BiVAD in the more recent cohort may have been additional factors influencing rates of bleeding and reexploration. We have found the graft to also allow improved control at the time of transplantation or explantation of the assist device (Figure 6).

The use of a PTFE graft to facilitate perfusion via the innominate artery during CPB is well described in the repair of interrupted aortic arch and the Norwood procedure and for repeat sternotomy. 5,6 We have found it to be a useful modification in the implantation of the BHE for two main reasons. First, it allows for a much greater length of ascending aorta to be available for the BHE outflow cannula anastomosis, particularly in small infants where the BHE cannula is relatively big compared with the length of the ascending aorta. The second and the most important advantage has been at the time of transplantation or explantation. Following implantation of VAD, we have observed a marked inflammatory response in the mediastinum resulting in tough adhesions, even after a short period of time from implantation. Therefore, the dissection of adhesions to the heart and cannulae can be quite troublesome in these conditions, and the availability of rapid arterial access for CPB constitutes a significant advantage in terms of safety. The area exposed above the innominate vein, particularly after thymectomy in children, is quite wide and able to easily accommodate the graft. We have not observed any cases of innominate or subclavian vein obstruction as a result of leaving the graft in situ. One patient required superior vena cava stenting for obstruction after heart transplantation but well below the level of the innominate vein. Even in the presence of tough adhesions, this area is easy to dissect and the graft is easily found. In one child, the implantation of graft was, however, not possible because of a dissection of the right carotid artery at the time of previous cardiac surgery. We have not observed any clinically relevant neurological cerebroembolic sequelae from using this cannulation/recannulation technique. However, we have not performed routine radiological imaging, and the possibility of an increased rate of microembolization as a result of this technique, therefore, cannot be completely excluded.

In conclusion, we present our experience with what we believe to be two very useful modifications of the implantation technique for the BHE assist device. These modifications have allowed for a sustained improvement in outcomes despite an increasing complexity of pediatric cardiac cases supported to transplantation or recovery using this device.
